column2: Event_Label
Event_Label
Sages (Shaunaka, etc.) perform a 12-year sacrifice in Naimisha forest.
The storyteller Ugrashrava Sauti arrives at the sacrifice.
The rishis, gathered for the sacrifice, ask Sauti to narrate the Mahabharata.
Sauti explains he heard the epic from Vaishampayana.
Vaishampayana had recited the epic at King Janamejaya's snake sacrifice.
Sauti provides a brief summary of all 18 parvas of the Mahabharata.
King Parikshit (Janamejaya's great-grandfather) is cursed to die by a snake bite.
Sage Veda's disciple, Uttanka, needs to pay his guru-dakshina.
The teacher's wife asks Uttanka to fetch the divine earrings of Queen Madayanti.
The serpent king Takshaka steals the earrings from Uttanka.
Uttanka faces many trials but eventually retrieves the earrings.
Uttanka vows revenge on Takshaka for the theft and trouble.
Uttanka goes to King Janamejaya and instigates him to avenge his father.
King Parikshit is killed by the serpent king Takshaka.
The Rakshasa Puloman abducts Sage Bhrigu's wife, Pauloma.
Their son, Chyavana, is born prematurely from the womb.
Chyavana's divine radiance burns the Rakshasa Puloman to ashes.
Sage Bhrigu curses Agni (Fire God) to become an "eater of all things."
Devas and Asuras churn the cosmic ocean to obtain Amrita (nectar).
The poison Halahala emerges and is swallowed by Lord Shiva.
The nectar of immortality, Amrita, finally emerges from the ocean.
The sisters Kadru (mother of Nagas) and Vinata (mother of Garuda) make a wager.
Kadru tricks Vinata by having her serpent-sons cover the horse's tail.
Vinata loses the wager and becomes Kadru's slave.
Garuda, Vinata's son, is born as a mighty eagle-god.
To free his mother, Garuda agrees to fetch the Amrita for the Nagas.
Garuda fights and defeats the Devas to retrieve the nectar.
Garuda makes a deal with Vishnu (becomes his mount) and Indra (snakes become his food).
Garuda places the Amrita on sharp kusha grass for the Nagas.
The Nagas go to purify themselves before drinking the nectar.
Indra swoops in and reclaims the Amrita while the Nagas are away.
The Nagas lick the sharp kusha grass in haste, splitting their tongues.
Garuda's mother, Vinata, is freed from slavery.
Kadru had earlier cursed her sons (Nagas) to be destroyed in a fire sacrifice.
The serpent king Vasuki, fearing the curse, arranges his sister Jaratkaru's marriage.
The sage Astika is born to Jaratkaru (serpent) and Jaratkaru (sage).
King Janamejaya begins the Sarpa Satra (snake sacrifice).
Snakes by the thousands are pulled into the sacrificial fire.
The serpent king Takshaka seeks refuge with Lord Indra.
The young sage Astika arrives at the sacrifice.
Astika impresses King Janamejaya with his wisdom and praise.
Janamejaya offers Astika a boon.
Astika asks for the snake sacrifice to be stopped.
Bound by his word, Janamejaya ends the Sarpa Satra.
Takshaka and the remaining serpent race are saved.
The snake sacrifice is concluded.
King Janamejaya asks Vaishampayana to narrate the history of his ancestors.
Vaishampayana explains the divine incarnations of gods and demons on Earth.
King Dushyanta meets Shakuntala in the forest.
Dushyanta and Shakuntala have a gandharva (love) marriage.
Dushyanta gives Shakuntala a royal ring and returns to his kingdom.
Dushyanta, under a curse, forgets Shakuntala.
Shakuntala, pregnant, arrives at Dushyanta's court.
Dushyanta, having no memory, rejects Shakuntala.
A fisherman finds the royal ring in a fish.
Seeing the ring, Dushyanta's memory returns.
Dushyanta accepts Shakuntala and their son, Bharata.
King Yayati (ancestor) is cursed with premature old age.
Yayati asks his sons to swap their youth with him.
Only the youngest son, Puru, agrees and swaps his youth.
After 1000 years, Yayati returns the youth to Puru.
Yayati makes Puru his heir (the Paurava line).
King Shantanu of Hastinapur falls in love with the goddess Ganga.
Ganga agrees to marry Shantanu on the condition he never question her.
Ganga gives birth to seven sons and drowns each one.
When the eighth son is born, Shantanu confronts and stops Ganga.
Ganga reveals she is a goddess and the sons were the 8 Vasus, cursed to be mortal.
Ganga leaves Shantanu, taking the eighth son (Devavrata) with her.
Devavrata is trained by gods and sages.
Ganga returns the magnificent prince Devavrata to King Shantanu.
Shantanu later falls in love with Satyavati, a fisher-woman.
Satyavati's father refuses the marriage unless her son is made heir.
To fulfill his father's desire, Devavrata takes a vow of lifelong celibacy.
Devavrata is named Bhishma ("The One of the Terrible Vow").
Shantanu marries Satyavati.
Shantanu and Satyavati have two sons: Chitrangada and Vichitravirya.
Chitrangada dies young. Bhishma rules as regent for Vichitravirya.
Bhishma abducts the three Kashi princesses (Amba, Ambika, Ambalika) for Vichitravirya.
Princess Amba reveals she loves another king, Salva.
Bhishma releases Amba to go to her lover.
Amba's lover, King Salva, rejects her (as she was "won" by another).
Amba returns to Bhishma and demands he marry her.
Bhishma refuses to marry Amba, citing his vow of celibacy.
Enraged, Amba swears to be the cause of Bhishma's death.
Amba is later reborn as Shikhandi.
Vichitravirya marries Ambika and Ambalika.
Vichitravirya dies childless, leaving the dynasty without an heir.
Satyavati summons her first-born son, the sage Vyasa, to perform Niyoga.
Ambika closes her eyes in fear of Vyasa.
Dhritarashtra, son of Ambika and Vyasa, is born blind.
Ambalika turns pale with fear of Vyasa.
Pandu, son of Ambalika and Vyasa, is born pale.
Satyavati asks Vyasa to try again with Ambika.
Ambika sends her respectful maid to Vyasa instead.
Vidura, son of the maid and Vyasa, is born wise and righteous.
Dhritarashtra marries Gandhari.
Gandhari blindfolds herself for life in empathy for her husband.
Gandhari has a long, difficult pregnancy.
Gandhari gives birth to a hard mass of flesh.
Vyasa divides the mass of flesh into 101 pots.
100 Kaurava sons (led by Duryodhana) and 1 daughter (Dushala) are born.
Pandu marries Kunti and Madri.
Pandu is cursed by the sage Kindama to die if he embraces his wives.
Kunti reveals to Pandu she has a divine boon to invoke gods for children.
With Pandu's blessing, Kunti invokes Yama, begetting Yudhishthira.
With Pandu's blessing, Kunti invokes Vayu, begetting Bhima.
With Pandu's blessing, Kunti invokes Indra, begetting Arjuna.
Kunti shares the mantra with Madri.
Madri invokes the Ashvini Kumaras, begetting the twins Nakula and Sahadeva.
(Flashback) As a young girl, Kunti tested her boon, invoking Surya.
Karna was born to Kunti and Surya, with divine armor and earrings.
Fearing shame, the unmarried Kunti set Karna adrift in a river.
Karna is found and raised by a charioteer, Adhiratha.
Pandu forgets his curse and embraces Madri in the forest.
The curse takes effect, and Pandu dies instantly.
Madri, in grief, commits sati on Pandu's funeral pyre.
Kunti is left to raise all five Pandavas.
Kunti and the five Pandavas return to the palace in Hastinapur.
The 100 Kauravas and 5 Pandavas grow up together.
Rivalry begins, especially between Duryodhana and Bhima.
Drona (Dronacharya) is appointed as the princes' teacher.
Drona holds a grudge against his childhood friend, King Drupada.
Arjuna excels at archery, becoming Drona's favorite.
Ekalavya, a tribal prince, is denied tutelage by Drona.
Ekalavya builds a statue of Drona and becomes a master archer.
Drona, fearing Ekalavya will surpass Arjuna, demands his right thumb as guru-dakshina.
Ekalavya gives his thumb to Drona without hesitation.
At a public exhibition, Arjuna is declared the supreme archer.
Karna appears and challenges Arjuna.
Karna is mocked for his low (charioteer) birth.
Duryodhana, seeing an ally, crowns Karna King of Anga.
The lifelong friendship between Duryodhana and Karna is sealed.
The lifelong rivalry between Karna and Arjuna is sealed.
Drona asks for his guru-dakshina: the defeat of King Drupada.
The Kauravas attack Drupada but fail.
The Pandavas (led by Arjuna) attack Drupada and succeed, capturing him.
Drona takes half of Drupada's kingdom as his revenge.
The humiliated King Drupada performs a great sacrifice.
From the sacrifice, Dhrishtadyumna is born (to kill Drona).
From the sacrifice, Draupadi is born (to marry Arjuna).
Duryodhana's jealousy of the Pandavas and their popularity grows.
Advised by Shakuni, Duryodhana convinces Dhritarashtra to send Pandavas to Varanavata.
Duryodhana has a palace of highly flammable materials (lac, resin) built in Varanavata.
Vidura learns of the plot to burn the Pandavas alive.
Vidura warns Yudhishthira in a coded message.
Vidura sends a miner to the Pandavas.
The miner digs a secret escape tunnel from the lacquer house.
Kunti holds a feast at the palace.
A forest woman and her five sons attend the feast, get drunk, and fall asleep.
Bhima sets fire to the lacquer house himself.
The Pandavas and Kunti escape through the secret tunnel into the forest.
The charred remains of the woman and her five sons are found.
The world (Hastinapur) believes the Pandavas and Kunti are dead.
The Pandavas and Kunti are discovered by the Rakshasa Hidimba and his sister Hidimbi.
Hidimba sends Hidimbi to lure the humans for him to eat.
Hidimbi falls in love with Bhima.
Hidimbi warns Bhima about her brother's plan.
Hidimba, enraged at the delay, attacks the Pandavas.
Bhima fights and kills the Rakshasa Hidimba.
Kunti allows Bhima to marry the kind Hidimbi.
Ghatotkacha (half-human, half-rakshasa) is born to Bhima and Hidimbi.
Ghatotkacha promises to return whenever the Pandavas need him.
The Pandavas, disguised as Brahmins, take shelter in the town of Ekachakra.
They learn the town is terrorized by the demon Bakasura.
Bakasura demands a weekly tribute of a cart of food and one human.
The Brahmin host family's turn arrives to provide the victim.
Kunti overhears the family's sorrow and volunteers Bhima to go.
Bhima takes the food cart to the demon's cave, eating all the food on the way.
The enraged Bakasura attacks Bhima.
Bhima pummels and kills Bakasura, freeing the town.
The Pandavas hear of the Swayamvara of Draupadi (princess of Panchala).
The Pandavas decide to attend the Swayamvara, still disguised as Brahmins.
On the way, they encounter the Gandharva Angaraparna.
Arjuna defeats Angaraparna in battle.
Angaraparna tells them the story of Tapati and Samvarana.
The Pandavas arrive at King Drupada's court in Panchala.
Drupada has set an "impossible" test: string a divine bow and shoot a fish's eye using only its reflection.
All the great kings and princes, including Duryodhana and Shalya, fail the test.
Karna succeeds in stringing the bow.
Draupadi declares she will not marry a suta-putra (charioteer's son).
The disguised Arjuna steps up to the challenge.
Arjuna effortlessly strings the bow and pierces the fish's eye.
Draupadi garlands Arjuna, choosing him as her husband.
The other kings, outraged that a Brahmin won, attack.
Bhima and Arjuna fight and defeat the enraged kings.
Krishna and Balarama, who are present, recognize the Pandavas.
The Pandavas return to their hut with Draupadi.
They call out to Kunti, "We have brought back a great alms!"
Kunti, without looking, replies, "You must share it equally among you."
Kunti sees Draupadi and is horrified by her own words.
Yudhishthira declares his mother's word cannot be taken back.
The sage Vyasa arrives to resolve the dilemma.
Vyasa explains Draupadi's past life: she prayed to Shiva five times for a husband.
Vyasa states the polyandrous marriage is her destiny.
King Drupada agrees to the arrangement.
Draupadi is formally married to all five Pandava brothers.
News that the Pandavas are alive and allied with Drupada reaches Hastinapur.
Dhritarashtra, fearing their new power, feigns happiness.
Dhritarashtra sends Vidura to Panchala to invite the Pandavas back.
The Pandavas and Draupadi return to Hastinapur.
The elders (Bhishma, Drona, Vidura) advise Dhritarashtra to divide the kingdom.
Dhritarashtra gives the Pandavas the barren forest-land of Khandavaprastha.
Duryodhana and the Kauravas keep the fertile, prosperous Hastinapur.
The Pandavas accept the "barren" half of the kingdom.
With help from Krishna and the Asura architect Maya, the Pandavas clear the forest.
The Pandavas build the magnificent new capital city of Indraprastha.
The Pandavas and Draupadi establish a rule for their polyandrous marriage.
The rule: If one brother enters the room while Draupadi is with another, he must go into a 12-year exile.
A Brahmin's cows are stolen, and he begs Arjuna for help.
Arjuna's weapons are in the room where Yudhishthira and Draupadi are.
To uphold his dharma, Arjuna breaks the pact and enters the room.
Arjuna retrieves his weapons and saves the Brahmin's cows.
Despite protests, Arjuna insists on honoring the pact and goes into exile for 12 years.
During his exile, Arjuna marries the Naga princess Ulupi.
During his exile, Arjuna marries Chitrangada, princess of Manipur.
A son, Babruvahana, is born to Arjuna and Chitrangada.
Towards the end of his exile, Arjuna travels to Dwarka.
Arjuna falls in love with Subhadra, Krishna's sister.
Krishna advises Arjuna to "abduct" Subhadra, as it is a heroic Kshatriya custom.
Arjuna abducts Subhadra.
With Krishna's blessing, Arjuna and Subhadra are married.
A son, Abhimanyu, is later born to Arjuna and Subhadra.
Arjuna returns to Indraprastha with his new wife, Subhadra.
Draupadi, after initial jealousy, accepts Subhadra as a co-wife.
Draupadi gives birth to five sons (one from each Pandava), the Upapandavas.
Agni (Fire God) suffers from indigestion and needs to burn the Khandava forest.
Lord Indra protects the forest, as it is home to his friend, the serpent Takshaka.
Agni asks Krishna and Arjuna for help to burn the forest.
Krishna and Arjuna agree to help Agni.
To battle Indra, Agni gives the Gandiva bow to Arjuna.
To battle Indra, Agni gives the Sudarshana Chakra to Krishna.
Krishna and Arjuna fight off Indra and all other gods/demons trying to stop the fire.
The entire Khandava forest is burnt to the ground, curing Agni.
Only a few beings are saved: the Asura architect Maya and the serpent Takshaka (who was absent).
(Link to next Parva) The Pandavas are established in Indraprastha with divine weapons, setting the stage for the Sabha Parva.
Maya, the Asura architect saved from the Khandava fire, approaches the Pandavas.
In gratitude, Maya offers to build a magnificent, one-of-a-kind assembly hall (Sabha) for Yudhishthira.
Maya builds the unparalleled palace at Indraprastha, filled with illusions (water looks like floor, floor looks like water).
Maya retrieves and presents a divine club (gada) to Bhima.
Maya gives the divine conch shell, Devadatta, to Arjuna.
The great sage Narada visits the Pandavas in their new Sabha.
Narada describes the even greater, divine assembly halls of Indra, Varuna, Kubera, Yama, and Brahma.
Narada delivers a message from King Pandu in heaven.
Pandu's message: He longs for Yudhishthira to perform the Rajasuya Yagna and achieve the status of Samrat (Emperor).
The seed for the Rajasuya Yagna is planted in Yudhishthira's mind.
Yudhishthira hesitates, as the Rajasuya requires conquering kings, which involves violence.
Yudhishthira summons Krishna for counsel regarding the Yagna.
Krishna supports the idea, stating Yudhishthira is worthy of the title of Emperor.
Krishna warns Yudhishthira of one supreme obstacle: Jarasandha, the King of Magadha.
Krishna explains Jarasandha has imprisoned 86 kings to be sacrificed.
Krishna states the Rajasuya Yagna is impossible as long as Jarasandha lives.
Krishna devises a plan to kill Jarasandha in a duel, not a conventional war.
Krishna, Bhima, and Arjuna travel to Magadha disguised as Brahmins.
They reveal their identities and challenge Jarasandha to a duel.
Jarasandha, a great warrior, chooses the mighty Bhima as his opponent.
Bhima and Jarasandha engage in a ferocious wrestling match that lasts for 14 days.
Bhima is unable to kill Jarasandha because the king's body magically rejoins when split.
Krishna signals Bhima by tearing a blade of grass in two and throwing the halves in opposite directions.
Bhima understands the signal, rips Jarasandha's body in two, and throws the halves in opposite directions.
Jarasandha is permanently killed.
The Pandavas free the 86 kings imprisoned by Jarasandha.
The 86 liberated kings, in gratitude, swear allegiance to Yudhishthira for his Rajasuya Yagna.
To be declared Emperor, Yudhishthira dispatches his brothers on the Digvijaya (Conquest of the World).
Arjuna goes North and conquers all kingdoms.
Bhima goes East and conquers all kingdoms.
Sahadeva goes South and conquers all kingdoms.
Nakula goes West and conquers all kingdoms.
All four brothers return to Indraprastha victorious, with immense treasure and the fealty of all kings.
The Rajasuya Yagna begins at Indraprastha.
Kings, sages, and Brahmins from every known land are invited.
Yudhishthira honors guests by assigning them ceremonial duties.
Duryodhana is made treasurer, forcing him to receive the massive tributes and fueling his jealousy.
The ceremony is a magnificent success.
Yudhishthira is consecrated as Chakravartin Samrat (Emperor of the World).
At the Yagna's climax, it is time to give the Arghya (first offering of honor) to the most pre-eminent guest.
The elder Bhishma declares that Lord Krishna is the greatest and most divine being present and deserves the first honor.
Yudhishthira agrees, and Sahadeva begins the rites to honor Krishna.
Shishupala, King of Chedi, is enraged by Krishna's selection for the first honor.
Shishupala stands and violently insults Krishna, Bhishma, and Yudhishthira in front of the entire assembly.
(Flashback) Krishna had promised his aunt (Shishupala's mother) to forgive her son 100 offenses.
Krishna calmly counts each of Shishupala's insults.
Shishupala crosses the 100-offense limit with his tirade.
Krishna declares his vow is complete and summons his Sudarshana Chakra.
The Sudarshana Chakra flies across the hall and beheads Shishupala.
Shishupala's soul is seen as a bright light merging into Krishna's body.
The Rajasuya Yagna is successfully completed.
After the Yagna, Duryodhana stays to tour Maya's magical palace.
Duryodhana is utterly humiliated by the illusions, falling into a pool he thought was a floor.
Bhima, Draupadi, and others laugh at Duryodhana's misfortune.
Duryodhana returns to Hastinapur, consumed by a "fever of jealousy."
Duryodhana tells his uncle, Shakuni, that he wants to die.
Shakuni devises a plot to defeat the Pandavas.
Shakuni: "Yudhishthira loves to gamble... I will play on your behalf with my loaded dice and win his kingdom."
Duryodhana convinces his father, Dhritarashtra, to approve the plan.
Dhritarashtra summons the Pandavas to Hastinapur for a "friendly game of dice."
Yudhishthira, bound by the Kshatriya code, feels he must accept the challenge.
The game begins, with Shakuni playing on Duryodhana's behalf.
Shakuni, using his magical loaded dice, wins every single throw.
Yudhishthira first bets and loses his jewels and treasury.
Yudhishthira bets and loses his army, chariots, and elephants.
Yudhishthira bets and loses his entire kingdom of Indraprastha.
Yudhishthira bets and loses his brothers, one by one, as slaves.
Yudhishthira bets and loses himself, becoming a slave.
Shakuni taunts Yudhishthira: "You have one prize left—your wife, Draupadi."
Yudhishthira, in despair and with clouded judgment, bets Draupadi.
Shakuni rolls the dice and wins Draupadi.
Duryodhana orders his brother Dushasana to drag Draupadi into the assembly.
Dushasana seizes Draupadi (who is in her monthly course and wearing a single cloth) by the hair and drags her into the hall.
Draupadi asks the assembly the legal question: "Did Yudhishthira have the right to wager me after he had already lost himself?"
The elders (Bhishma, Drona) are silent, their heads bowed in shame.
Karna, siding with Duryodhana, calls Draupadi a slave.
Duryodhana orders Dushasana to disrobe Draupadi publicly.
Dushasana begins to pull at Draupadi's sari.
Draupadi, seeing no mortal will help her, prays to Lord Krishna.
Krishna performs a miracle, supplying an endless length of cloth.
Dushasana pulls until he collapses from exhaustion; Draupadi's honor is saved.
Enraged, Bhima swears an oath to tear open Dushasana's chest in battle and drink his blood.
Enraged, Bhima swears an oath to break Duryodhana's thigh (who had bared it to Draupadi).
Terrible omens (howling jackals, dark clouds) fill the land.
Dhritarashtra, terrified by the omens, finally intervenes.
Dhritarashtra offers Draupadi three boons to stop the omens.
Draupadi's first boon: Yudhishthira is freed from slavery.
Draupadi's second boon: Her other four husbands and their weapons are freed.
Draupadi refuses a third boon.
Dhritarashtra restores the Pandavas' kingdom, wealth, and freedom.
The Pandavas are allowed to return to Indraprastha.
Duryodhana, furious at this reversal, confronts Dhritarashtra.
Duryodhana argues the Pandavas will now be filled with vengeance and will destroy them.
Duryodhana convinces Dhritarashtra to call the Pandavas back for one final game of dice.
The terms of the final game: 12 years of forest exile + 1 year incognito. If discovered, the exile repeats.
Yudhishthira is summoned again and, bound by the code, feels he cannot refuse.
The final game is played, and Shakuni wins.
The Pandavas and Draupadi are forced to remove their royal robes and wear the bark of trees.
The Pandavas and Draupadi are banished and begin their 12-year exile in the forest.
The Sabha Parva ends, leading into the Vana Parva.
The Pandavas & Draupadi begin their 12-year exile + 1-year incognito.
They remove their royal robes and wear tree bark.
Many loyal Brahmins and citizens follow the Pandavas into the Kamyaka forest.
Yudhishthira is distressed, as he has no food to offer his followers.
Yudhishthira prays to the Sun God, Surya.
Surya grants Yudhishthira the Akshaya Patra (The Inexhaustible Vessel).
The pot produces an endless supply of food each day until Draupadi has eaten.
(In Hastinapur) Vidura furiously condemns Dhritarashtra's actions.
Duryodhana, enraged, insults Vidura.
Vidura briefly leaves Hastinapur and joins the Pandavas in the forest.
Dhritarashtra, realizing his folly, sends Sanjaya to bring Vidura back.
Krishna visits the Pandavas in the Kamyaka forest.
Draupadi laments her humiliation to Krishna.
Krishna vows he will ensure the Pandavas are victorious and their enemies are destroyed.
The Pandavas move to the Dvaita forest.
The Rakshasa Kirmira (brother of Bakasura) attacks the Pandavas.
Bhima fights and kills the demon Kirmira.
The sage Vyasa visits the Pandavas.
Vyasa advises the Pandavas to use their exile to acquire divine weapons.
Vyasa instructs Arjuna to travel to the Himalayas to propitiate Lord Shiva.
Arjuna undertakes the difficult journey and performs severe penance.
Lord Shiva, disguised as a Kirata (mountain hunter), appears to test Arjuna.
A demon disguised as a great wild boar charges at Arjuna.
Both Arjuna and the Kirata shoot the boar at the same time.
Arjuna and the Kirata argue over who killed the boar.
The argument escalates into a fierce duel.
The Kirata effortlessly counters all of Arjuna's attacks and divine weapons.
Arjuna is disarmed, wrestles the hunter, and is overpowered.
A humiliated Arjuna creates a mud lingam and prays to Shiva.
A flower placed on the lingam magically appears on the hunter's head.
Arjuna realizes the hunter is Lord Shiva.
Pleased, Shiva grants Arjuna the Pashupatastra, his most powerful weapon.
The other gods appear, and Arjuna is taken to Indraloka (heaven) by his father, Indra.
Arjuna spends five years in heaven mastering all celestial weapons (Astras).
The Apsara Urvashi becomes infatuated with Arjuna.
Arjuna politely rejects Urvashi, viewing her as a mother-figure.
Angered, Urvashi curses Arjuna to become a eunuch (Kliba).
Indra modifies the curse to last for only one year.
Indra tells Arjuna this curse will be the perfect disguise for his 13th year incognito.
The remaining Pandavas (missing Arjuna) embark on a great pilgrimage (Tirtha-yatra).
A divine Saugandhika flower wafts by Draupadi.
Draupadi, enchanted, asks Bhima to fetch more.
On his quest, Bhima's path is blocked by an old monkey (Hanuman).
Bhima arrogantly orders the monkey to move.
Hanuman, still disguised, asks Bhima to just move his tail.
Bhima tries to lift the tail but cannot budge it, even with all his strength.
Humbled, Bhima realizes the monkey is divine.
The monkey reveals himself as Hanuman, Bhima's spiritual brother (both sons of Vayu).
Hanuman blesses Bhima and promises to sit on Arjuna's flag in the future war.
Bhima continues his quest and reaches Kubera's celestial garden.
Bhima is confronted by Yaksha and Rakshasa guards, including the demon Manimana.
Bhima kills the guards and Manimana and gathers the flowers for Draupadi.
A Rakshasa named Jatasura, disguised as a Brahmin, gains the Pandavas' trust.
While Bhima is away, Jatasura seizes Draupadi, Yudhishthira, Nakula, and Sahadeva.
Bhima returns, tracks Jatasura, and kills him in a brutal fight.
The Pandavas are joyfully reunited with Arjuna, who returns from heaven.
Sage Brihadashva tells Yudhishthira the Story of Nala and Damayanti.
(Nala's Story) Righteous King Nala has a weakness for dice and is tricked by the evil spirit Kali.
(Nala's Story) Nala loses his kingdom and is separated from his wife, Damayanti.
(Nala's Story) After years of suffering, Nala overcomes Kali and wins back his kingdom.
The story consoles Yudhishthira regarding his own gambling addiction.
Sage Markandeya tells Yudhishthira the Ramopakhyana (Story of Rama).
(Rama's Story) Lord Rama, a divine incarnation, also suffered a long exile and had his wife abducted by Ravana.
The story gives Yudhishthira comfort and resolve, showing that even gods suffer.
Sage Markandeya tells the Story of Savitri and Satyavan.
(Savitri's Story) Savitri knowingly marries Satyavan, who is fated to die in one year.
(Savitri's Story) On the fated day, Savitri follows Yama, the God of Death, who takes Satyavan's soul.
(Savitri's Story) Savitri impresses Yama with her intelligence and devotion.
(Savitri's Story) Savitri cleverly tricks Yama into granting a boon that requires him to return Satyavan's life.
(Savitri's Story) Yama, defeated by her wit, restores Satyavan to life.
Duryodhana learns of the Pandavas' suffering in the forest.
Advised by Karna and Shakuni, Duryodhana plans to travel to the forest to mock the Pandavas.
Duryodhana and his entire court travel under the pretext of a Ghosha-yatra (cattle-drive).
Duryodhana's party clashes with Gandharvas led by their king, Chitrasena.
The Gandharvas defeat the Kuru army, and even Karna is forced to flee.
The Gandharva king Chitrasena captures Duryodhana.
Some of Duryodhana's men escape and beg the Pandavas for help.
Bhima is delighted, but Yudhishthira scolds him.
Yudhishthira: "Against an outside foe, we are one hundred and five brothers." He orders a rescue.
Arjuna and Bhima attack the Gandharvas.
Arjuna (who is friends with Chitrasena) non-lethally defeats them and frees Duryodhana.
Duryodhana is ultimately humiliated by being rescued by the Pandavas.
Ashamed, Duryodhana contemplates suicide but is goaded back to Hastinapur by Shakuni.
Duryodhana, bent on revenge, learns of the Akshaya Patra's limitation (it's empty after Draupadi eats).
Duryodhana sends the short-tempered sage Durvasa and his thousands of disciples to visit the Pandavas after Draupadi has eaten.
Duryodhana's plan: The Pandavas will fail to feed Durvasa, who will then curse them to oblivion.
Draupadi, with an empty pot, panics and prays to Krishna.
Krishna instantly appears and asks for food.
Draupadi finds a single grain of rice left in the pot.
Krishna eats the single grain of rice.
Krishna's satisfaction causes the entire universe (including Durvasa's party) to feel full.
Durvasa and his disciples, fearing the Pandavas' power, flee without returning.
The Pandavas are out hunting, leaving Draupadi alone at the ashram.
Jayadratha, King of Sindhu (Dushala's husband), passes by the ashram.
Captivated by Draupadi, Jayadratha forcibly abducts her.
The Pandavas return, learn of the abduction, and give chase.
Bhima and Arjuna capture Jayadratha.
Yudhishthira stops Bhima from killing Jayadratha, to spare their sister Dushala from widowhood.
As an alternative punishment, Bhima shaves Jayadratha's head, leaving five mocking tufts.
The humiliation fills Jayadratha with a burning hatred for the Pandavas.
The 12 years of exile are almost complete.
The Pandavas are overcome with thirst in the forest.
Sahadeva, Nakula, Arjuna, and Bhima go one-by-one in search of water.
Each of the four brothers finds a beautiful, clear lake.
A voice (a Yaksha) warns each brother: "Do not drink before answering my questions."
Each of the four brothers, in arrogance or desperation, ignores the warning, drinks, and immediately drops dead.
Yudhishthira follows and is horrified to find his four brothers lying dead.
The Yaksha's voice speaks to Yudhishthira, who agrees to answer the questions.
Yudhishthira correctly answers all the Yaksha's profound philosophical questions about life and Dharma.
The Yaksha, pleased, reveals he is Lord Yama (Dharma), Yudhishthira's divine father.
Yama offers to revive one of his brothers.
Yudhishthira chooses Nakula (his half-brother).
Yama is stunned and asks why not the more powerful Bhima or Arjuna.
Yudhishthira: "I, a son of Kunti, am alive. It is only just that a son of my father's other wife, Madri, should also live. This is my Dharma."
Overjoyed at his son's unwavering righteousness, Yama revives all four brothers.
Yama grants the boon that the Pandavas will not be recognized during their 13th year incognito.
The 12 years of the Vana Parva are complete.
The Pandavas prepare to move on to their 13th year of exile in the Virata Parva.
